sub_topic: Using the Fourier transform to analyze the behavior of networks
message_1: A communication network requires a signal to be transmitted with a frequency of 500 Hz. The signal is modulated onto a carrier wave of frequency 10,000 Hz. Determine the frequency range of the modulated signal using Fourier analysis.
message_2:
When a signal with frequency 500 Hz is modulated onto a carrier wave of frequency 10,000 Hz, the resulting modulated signal will have sidebands at the sum and difference of the carrier and signal frequencies. This is a result of the modulation process, which can be analyzed using Fourier analysis.

The lower sideband frequency is the difference between the carrier and signal frequencies:
Lower sideband frequency = Carrier frequency - Signal frequency
Lower sideband frequency = 10,000 Hz - 500 Hz = 9,500 Hz

The upper sideband frequency is the sum of the carrier and signal frequencies:
Upper sideband frequency = Carrier frequency + Signal frequency
Upper sideband frequency = 10,000 Hz + 500 Hz = 10,500 Hz

Therefore, the frequency range of the modulated signal is from 9,500 Hz to 10,500 Hz.
